View and Manage vNode Configuration Details

Use this task to view configuration information for a vNode, and manage vNode parameters.

  1. Use any of the following ways to access the Device Summary window:
    • Log into the PW EMS, this window displays by default.
    • From the navigation bar, click Dashboard.
    • From the navigation bar, click Devices > Device Summary.
  2. In the Device Summary window, select the vNode row.
  3. Click the Actions column button .
  4. In the pop-up menu that appears, click vNode > Config Details as shown below.
  5. The Device Status window displays whether the vNode is configured and provides its device and system information. In the following example, the vNode can be determined by viewing the highlighted portion of its Device ID:
  6. Click Action.
  7. In the Perform Action on Device window select Action from the Select Command Type drop-down list.
  8. The Select Action Command drop-down list appears. Select from the following Select Action Command drop-down list actions:

    Field

    Description
    Request Log Records from Access Nodes Sends all logs from access devices to the PW EMS.
    Request PWS Csv Upload Logs from Access Nodes Sends all Public Warning System (PWS) logs from HNG node to the PW EMS.
    Reboot Access Node Device Reboots the vNodes and its cells.
    Reboot System Access Node Device Reboots all cells that are associated with this vNode.
  9. Select Show from the Select Command Type select from the following Select Show Command drop-down list actions:

    Field

    Description
    Show PKI Certificates Displays applicable access device PKI certificates.
    Show RF Signal Path Displays the E-UTRA Transmit and Receive RF signal paths.
    Show RF Port Displays RF ports on the access device.
  10. Click the back button on your Web browser to return to the Device Status window and click Modify to change existing vNode system, cell, and HNG node Information. In the System Information tab (which displays by default), the following vNode system fields can be modified as described in the table below:

    Field

    Description
    Version Displays the version of the vNode device.
    Device Name The default name of the vNode device is a number such as 41733-C19999-S392384X9B21815-01-4G. This number can be changed to a conventional name. For example: vNode_Dallas1
    Ping Interval The default value is 60 seconds for heartbeat pings to the vNode. You can set a new value from 3 to 3,600 seconds.
    Max Retry The default number of heartbeat ping retry intervals are 4. You can set a new value from 1 to 20 ping retries.
    LTE Sampling Frequency The default interval for LTE sampling of frequency is once every 15 minutes. You can set a new value from 0 to 60 minutes.
    Resources Sampling Frequency The default interval for bandwidth resource sampling is once every 15 minutes. You can set a new value from 0 to 60 minutes.
    Network Sampling Frequency The default interval for network sampling of frequency is once every 15 minutes. You can set a new value from 0 to 60 minutes.
    UMTS Sampling Frequency The default interval for Universal Mobile Telecommunications System (UMTS) sampling of frequency is once every 15 minutes. You can set a new value from 0 to 60 minutes.
    GSM Sampling Frequency The default interval for Global System for Mobile Communication (GSM) sampling of frequency is once every 15 minutes. You can set a new value from 0 to 60 minutes.
    NOTE: Other fields listed in this window cannot be modified.
  11. Different types of cell tabs can display for the vNode depending on its cell model support. If the vNode is configured for 4G LTE Option 8, it supports 2 cells and two tabs display. For example, Cell1-LTE tab and Cell2-LTE tab. A vNode can also support 2G GSM cells and display tabs with parameters that pertain to this type of cell. You can use the cell tabs to make a variety cell service parameter changes and perform searches for specific parameters to modify them by using their respective TR-069 parameter names.
  12. Click the HNG Information tab. The following Downlink Profiles can be selected for the vNode 2G or 4G services. The following table shows services that can be selected for a vNode that supports 4G LTE cells:

    Field

    Description
    LTE Service Name The name of the virtual eNodeB (VeNB) service from the PW EMS to this cell. For example, venb01. This VeNB service includes the configuration of the Public Land Mobile Network (PLMN) identifier (ID), E-UTRAN Node B (eNB) ID, Mobility Management Entity (MME) IP addresses, the Tracking Area Code (TAC), emergency area (EA) ID, and so on. SON provisions a unique eNodeB name to every vNode so vNode duplication does not occur. The PW EMS has the ability to identify any duplicate vNode by accepting the S1-Setup request from the latest vNode and break the S1 link with the previous vNode. The VeNB service can help inform the SON service on the PW EMS about the S1AP link down status.
    DownlinkQoS Select the configured downlink QoS profile for this vNode, which indicates the Differentiated Services Code Point (DSCP) that is applied to data traffic from the HNG to access network devices, such as the RRH. Refer to the Configure Downlink QoS section for more information about configuring this profile.
    DownlinkShaping Select the configured downlink QoS shaping profile for this vNode, which indicates the DSCP that is applied to data traffic towards access devices such as an RRH from the HNG. Refer to the Configure Downlink QoS Shapping section for more information about configuring this profile.
    Downlink Bandwidth The default downlink bandwidth for the vNode is one minute. You can enter a new value from 1 to 2000 minutes.
    TAC drop-down list The default TAC that indicates the traffic area in which an eNodeB (eNB) belongs is 12593. This TAC is unique within a PLMN. You can optionally select 12594 as the TAC.
  13. Click SUBMIT to finish modifying the vBBU system parameters.
Parent topic: View Device Summary Information
